Event.EventName: MLK Day of Service
Event.EventDescription:
We're glad you're interested in our MLK Day of Service!

Volunteers can choose one of two different service sites when registering. We will make every effort to assign volunteers to their first choice project, but assignments will be made on a first-come, first-served basis, so sign up early.

Monday, January 18

Catman2 (8:45 AM - 11:15 AM Cullowhee) (4 total spots available)
Catman2 is Cullowhee's no-kill, cats-only shelter. Volunteers will help with cleaning up around the shelter, as well as socializing/playing with the cats.

Roadside Clean Up (10:00 AM - 11:30 AM, Cullowhee) (9 total spots available)
Volunteers will help to clean up a roadside near campus.

_________________________________________________________________________________________

*You will receive a confirmation email with details & your assigned site on Friday, January 15. 
*If you have any questions, please contact Amanda Hanson at ahanson@wcu.edu. 

Registration will close at 5 PM on Thursday, January 14.

Event.EventName: Ann Miller Woodford: The Artist as Storyteller
Event.EventDescription:
Ann Miller Woodford is a visual artist, designer, and entrepreneur, a creative person no matter what she is working on. In her early 70s, she has dedicated the rest of her life to painting and drawing the spirit she feels and treasures around her, while uplifting young people and adults. Using oils, she calls her works representational, mostly southern genre; however, she is skilled at drawing in pencil, charcoal, and ink. She says, “I am motivated by people, animals, clouds, trees, rocks… Inspiration never stops!”

Artwork from acclaimed artist and author Ann Woodford, native of Cherokee County, NC.

On display 1/25/21 – 3/1/21

Event.EventName: Take and Make: Mural *RSVP Required*
Event.EventDescription:
Take a canvas to paint on LMP! Show us your finished canvas by Feb. 2nd to be featured on our social media! RSVPs will open 1 week before the event. 

Make sure to check out our social media for updates, Facebook or Instagram.

There are different listings for times to sign up and you must arrive during the time you RSVPed. If you cannot come during the time you have RSVPed for, it will be marked as a "no-show" and you will be given a warning. You must be present to get the item (no one else can pick up for you). If you do not arrive by the end of the event, your item may be given to another student. The event is 1 item per student. Do not show up prior to the time you have RSVPed.

*Participants must RSVP through Engage to attend an in-person event. All in-person events will have limited capacity in accordance with mass gathering guidelines and participants will be required to follow safety procedures including, but not limited to, self-screening, wearing a face covering over nose and mouth, and maintaining prescribed physical distance.

**All events this semester are subject to change.

Our Department wants to ensure that all students are able to participate. By RSVPing, you are making a commitment to attend. If you fail to show up to an event 3 times, we reserve the right to no longer allow you to RSVP to events.

Event.EventName: Information Session: Wells Fargo Technology University Programs Overview
Event.EventDescription:
You’re invited to participate in the virtual - Meet the Recruiters and Analyst – Wells Fargo Technology University Programs Overview!


If you are interested in a career in technology with an expected graduation date of December 2020 – June 2023, we invite you to join us virtually January 26th, 2021 at 7:00pm EST, 6:00pm CST, and 4:00pm PST for our Meet the Recruiters and Analyst Chat.

As part of this virtual event, you will hear from a panel of Wells Fargo Technology team member’s personal journeys moving from college to their career roles as well as their experiences working for Wells Fargo. You will also have the chance to hear from the Wells Fargo Technology University Program Recruiting Team regarding application and interview processes.


You may also have the opportunity to schedule for an interview for our Wells Fargo Technology Summer Intern and Associate Program 2021 positions within multiple divisions of Wells Fargo Technology.

Meet the Recruiters and Analyst details:
January 26th, 2021 at 7:00pm EST, 6:00pm CST, and 4:00pm PST This chat will be held virtually.

To attend the Wells Fargo Technology Meet the Recruiters and Analyst Chat you must Register Here by January 21st, 2021 at 11:59 pm EST.
If you have any questions, please email Britton.Frampton@wellsfargo.com or Danielle.Stensrud@wellsfargo.com.

Event.EventName: Internship Q&A Webinar
Event.EventDescription:
Catamounts,

Learn what an internship is, how to find an internship, how to apply for internships and how to get ahead when planning for an internship during college.

I'll talk about paid vs unpaid internships. Remote vs in-person internships. Class credit vs not for class credit internships.

All you need to know about internships and then I will take questions.

Event.EventName: Full Moon Night Hike
Event.EventDescription:
Meeting Time: 7:00pm-10:00pm

Sign-up Deadline: 10/12 at noon

Student $5.00

What to Expect: By the light of the moon, join Base Camp on a short journey through our WCU Trail System as we help empower you to discover the natural world around campus and provide stratgies for being present and living in the moment. Students will learn mindfulness, grounding, breathing and other supportive techniques along with learning more about Leave No Trace and our natural world around us. It’s amazing how different even your favorite trails look when hiking by moonlight and at night.

NOTICE:
You are responsible for keeping up with your own equipment and any equipment assigned to you by Base Camp Cullowhee staff. Base Camp will assume no responsibility for lost or damaged personal or rental equipment. You must immediately report injuries/medical problems to a Base Camp guide. As with most outdoor activities serious injuries can occur such as dislocations, fractures, and head injuries, however the most common injuries are bumps and bruises. Please remember that you are accepting responsibility for these risks by participating in this activity. We take all precautions and with your help we can minimize these risks.

Register at myrec.wcu.edu

Event.EventName: Intercultural Dialogue and Cherokee Culture Presentation
Event.EventDescription:
Join us if you can, stay a while, bring just yourself or friends and family, share a recipe whether or not you cook it for the event.

Director of WCU's Cherokee Center, Sky Sampson, will have a presentation about Cherokee culture. We'll talk about upcoming meeting and enjoy each other's company.

An enrolled member of the Eastern Band, Sampson earned her bachelor’s degree in communication with a concentration in public relations at WCU in 2010 before going on to receive her master’s degree in human environmental sciences at the University of Alabama in 2014. She has served as program manager for the Cherokee Youth Council of the Cherokee Boys Club since May 2011. As director of the Cherokee Center, Sampson will serve as a liaison between WCU and the Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians.

We value your presence and will be honored that you have carved out some time from your busy lives and schedules to spend some time with us!
   

For more information about the group, please visit their website. 

 

Hosted By: We Walk Together: Intercultural Dialogue Group

Event.EventName: General Career & Internship Prep - Designing Your Path Crash Courses
Event.EventDescription:
This series is designed for those who are not seniors or grad students, but are looking for help getting ready for jobs or internships. Learn how to network, create an elevator pitch, write a resume & cover letter, and nail your next interview. 

The first session will be offered virtually and the next three will be in-person, socially distanced with masks, pending the guidance from the university on in-person classes. Each student that responds to the event will receive an email with more detailed instructions.

These sessions will be offered on Thursday starting on February 11th.

(Virtual) Thursday, Feb 11th: 3:30PM - 5:00PM

(In-Person) Thursday, Feb 18th: 3:30PM - 5:00PM

(In-Person) Thursday, Feb 25th: 3:30PM - 5:00PM

(In-Person) Thursday, March 4th: 3:30PM - 5:00PM

Event.EventName: Major Exploration - Designing Your Path Crash Courses
Event.EventDescription:
Are you having trouble picking a major that feels right for you? Or, do you want to know more about the different majors out there and what you can do with them? This is a special 4 week long course to help students find a major and learn more about themselves in the process. 

 

This course will be offered on Mondays and Thursdays starting February 8th, so you have to register before that date. Pick which day of the week works best for your schedule and RSVP for it below. 

 

The first session will be offered virtually and the next three will be in-person, socially distanced with masks, pending the guidance from the university on in-person classes. Each student that responds to the event will receive an email with more detailed instructions.


Course Option 1:

(Virtual) Monday, Feb 8th: 1PM - 2:30PM 

(In-person) Monday, Feb 15th: 1PM - 2:30PM

(In-person) Monday, Feb 22nd: 1PM - 2:30PM

(In-person) Monday, March 1st: 1PM - 2:30PM

Course Option 2:

(Virtual) Thursday, Feb 11th: 10AM - 11:30AM

(In-person) Thursday, Feb 18th: 10AM - 11:30AM

(In-person) Thursday, Feb 25th: 10AM - 11:30AM

(In-person) Thursday, March 4th: 10AM - 11:30AM

Event.EventName: Career Exploration - Designing Your Path Crash Courses
Event.EventDescription:
Do you want to learn more about the different career options out there? This series will allow students the opportunity to learn more about themselves and how their career fits in with their life. We will learn about how to research different career paths, reflect on what feels like a good fit, and envision the life you want to lead. You don't need to have anything figured out to attend this crash course, but we do recommend that you have selected a major at this point. 

 

This course will be offered on Mondays and Tuesdays starting February 8th, so you have to register before that date. Pick which day of the week works best for your schedule and RSVP for it below. 

The first session will be offered virtually and the next three will be in-person, socially distanced with masks, pending the guidance from the university on in-person classes. Each student that responds to the event will receive an email with more detailed instructions.

Are you getting close to graduating? Would you like help with getting ready for the job search? Feeling anxious and don't know where to start before graduating? 

This course is for Seniors or Grad Students that are looking to get ahead when it comes to job searching. In this course we will go over everything you need to start your job searching, from strategy tactics to the materials you will need. 

We will go over resumes, cover letters, LinkedIn, Interviewing, and more!

Event.EventName: Lifeguarding Certification Course
Event.EventDescription:
Register by February 5th for this American Red Cross certification class in the Campus Recreation Center or online at myrec.wcu.edu.  There is a cost associated with the certification.  All registrants must complete an online portion of the certification and provide proof of completion, prior to starting the in-class portion of the certification.

Participants must be able to pass the required pre-requistes:

    • Be at least 15 years old on or before the final scheduled session of the course.
    • Swim 300 yards, continuously demonstrating breath control and rhythmic breathing. Participants may swim using the front crawl, breaststroke or a combination of both, but swimming on the back or side is not allowed. Swim goggles may be used.
    • Tread water for 2 minutes, using only the legs. Participants should place their hands under the armpits.
  • Complete a timed event within 1 minute, 40 seconds:
    • Starting in the water, swim 20 yards. Swim goggles are not allowed.
    • Surface dive, feet-first or headfirst, to a depth of 7 to 10 feet to retrieve a 10-pound object.
    • Return to the surface and swim 20 yards on the back to return to the starting point with both hands holding the object and keeping the face at or near the surface so they are able to get a breath.
    • Exit the water without using a ladder or steps.

Event.EventName: Ann Miller Woodford: The Artist as Storyteller
Event.EventDescription:
Ann Miller Woodford is a visual artist, designer, and entrepreneur, a creative person no matter what she is working on. In her early 70s, she has dedicated the rest of her life to painting and drawing the spirit she feels and treasures around her, while uplifting young people and adults. Using oils, she calls her works representational, mostly southern genre; however, she is skilled at drawing in pencil, charcoal, and ink. She says, “I am motivated by people, animals, clouds, trees, rocks… Inspiration never stops!”

Artwork from acclaimed artist and author Ann Woodford, native of Cherokee County, NC.

On display 1/25/21 – 3/1/21

Event.EventName: Roots of Wisdom: Native Knowledge and Shared Science
Event.EventDescription:
Local ecosystems around the world face serious environmental challenges. Many Native communities have found innovative solutions by combining traditional knowledge with modern science. Roots of Wisdom: Native Knowledge. Shared Science features stories of ecological and cultural restoration from the Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation, Tulalip Tribes, Eastern Band of Cherokee Indians, and Native Hawaiians. A Smithsonian Travelling Exhibit


On display 3/15/21 - 8/22/21

Event.EventName: Rope Rug Making Workshop
Event.EventDescription:
Meeting Time: 5:00pm-8:00pm

Signup Deadline: 3/15

Student - $10.00

What to Expect: Ever wonder what a climber does with all that old retired climbing rope? Well, at Outdoor Programs we love to reduce, reuse and recycle our old gear! While old climbing rope can be a danger to the next user, we take ours and turn it into a durable spiral rug that looks great at any door step entrance or laundry room! Join Outdoor Programs for an evening of arts and crafts and learn how to make a spiral rope rug out of old climbing rope. The cost includes your supplies and 1 rope to make a rug. Your rug may take longer than the time allowed to complete it but don't worry we will allow you time afterwards to finish it. Physical distancing and face coverings will be required to participate.

Register at myrec.wcu.edu

Event.EventName: "I Don't Know What I'm Doing:" Understanding and Addressing Imposter Syndrome as an Entry-Level Professional
Event.EventDescription: It’s common for new professionals to feel uncertain about their abilities to perform their job well, even when they have proven their competencies and skill level. Imposter syndrome happens to more people than you think, even those who have been in their fields for a while. Learn more about Imposter Syndrome and strategies for addressing or overcoming feelings of inadequacy.

Event.EventName: Catamounts Outdoors: Leave No Trace Awareness Workshop
Event.EventDescription:
When & Where:
Meet Saturday, March 27th at 9:00am, in the front lobby of the Campus Recreation Center. Please be on time!

What to Expect:
Do you spend a lot of time recreating outside? Are you concerned about the potential impact humans can impose on the wild places you love? Join Outdoor Programs while you build your resume certifications and knowledge around Leave No Trace (LNT) Awareness. Leave No Trace(https://lnt.org/) is an organization whose sole purpose is to educate the public on how to be better stewards of the natural world we live in. Come hike and explore WCU's trail system while a LNT Master Educator explains more about how you can reduce your impact in the backcountry as well as around campus. Physical distancing and face coverings are required.

What to bring: Please plan for cool and warm weather. Below is a basic gear list that you should plan to bring inside of a small backpack.
·         Clothing appropriate for hiking, layers may be appropriate based on weather forcast
·         Small Backpack
·         Waterproof Jacket with a hood
·         Closed Toed Shoes for hiking
·         32 oz Water bottle
. *Face Covering Required
NOTICE:
You are responsible for keeping up with your own equipment and any equipment assigned to you by Base Camp Cullowhee staff. Base Camp will assume no responsibility for lost or damaged personal or rental equipment. You must immediately report injuries/medical problems to a Base Camp guide. As with most outdoor activities serious injuries can occur such as dislocations, fractures, and head injuries, however the most common injuries are bumps and bruises. Please remember that you are accepting responsibility for these risks by participating in this activity. We take all precautions and with your help we can minimize these risks.

Base Camp Cancellation Policy
 If the trip is cancelled by Base Camp Staff due to insufficient registration, unsafe conditions, or weather related circumstances patrons will receive a full refund or have the option to obtain credit towards a future outing.  If cancellation is made on the part of the patron, more than seven days before the trip date for full and half day trips, more than two weeks before the trip date for overnight trips and more than one month before the trip date for trips three days or longer, a full refund will be given.  Regardless of when you register, no refunds will be given, unless there are special circumstances, for cancellations made within seven days of the trip date for full and half day trips, two weeks before the trip date for overnight trips and one month before the trip date for trips three days or longer. Cancellations must be made in writing via email Monday-Friday between the hours of 8am-5pm.


If you have any additional questions, contact the Adventure Shop at 828.227.8813 or basecamp@wcu.edu

Register at myrec.wcu.edu

Event.EventName: Catamount Climb Half Marathon & 5K
Event.EventDescription:
Join Western Carolina University’s Department of Campus Recreation and Wellness and School of Health Sciences for the Catamount Climb Half Marathon and 5K, formerly known as the Valley of the Lilies Half Marathon and 5K.

The 2021 Catamount Climb Half Marathon and 5K will be held virtually this year in accordance with university, local, state and national guidelines.

Registered participants will have the opportunity to complete their distance (5K or Half Marathon) between April 5th – April 19th and submit their results online at Run SignUp!. This is a virtual race, so registered participants can run anywhere like a local park, neighborhood, trail system, track, or greenway.

Event.EventName: Working in Multigenerational Office
Event.EventDescription: There are now four generations in the workforce: Baby Boomers, Gen Xers, Millennials, and Gen Zers. Learn the foundations of what makes each generation unique and how each might view the world and the workplace. Implications and strategies for working with each generation will be covered.

Event.EventName: Catamounts Outdoors: Outdoor Photography 101 (Cell Phone)
Event.EventDescription:
When & Where:
Meet Wednesday, April 7th, at 5pm, in the front lobby of the Campus Recreation Center. Please be on time!

What to Expect:
In this workshop, participants will learn how to capture action photos with your phone. We will take a hike throughout the WCU trail system, and stop occasionally to discuss angles, lighting, motion, and creative ideas to help expand your action photos with your phone. Participants will create photos of mountain bikers and trail runners and stills on site with one-on-one help.   

What to bring: Please plan for cool and warm weather. Below is a basic gear list that you should plan to bring inside of a small backpack.
·         Clothing appropriate for hiking, layers may be appropriate based on weather forcast
·         Small Backpack
·         Waterproof Jacket with a hood
·         Closed Toed Shoes for hiking
·         32 oz Water bottle
. *Face Covering Required
NOTICE:
You are responsible for keeping up with your own equipment and any equipment assigned to you by Base Camp Cullowhee staff. Base Camp will assume no responsibility for lost or damaged personal or rental equipment. You must immediately report injuries/medical problems to a Base Camp guide. As with most outdoor activities serious injuries can occur such as dislocations, fractures, and head injuries, however the most common injuries are bumps and bruises. Please remember that you are accepting responsibility for these risks by participating in this activity. We take all precautions and with your help we can minimize these risks.

Base Camp Cancellation Policy
 If the trip is cancelled by Base Camp Staff due to insufficient registration, unsafe conditions, or weather related circumstances patrons will receive a full refund or have the option to obtain credit towards a future outing.  If cancellation is made on the part of the patron, more than seven days before the trip date for full and half day trips, more than two weeks before the trip date for overnight trips and more than one month before the trip date for trips three days or longer, a full refund will be given.  Regardless of when you register, no refunds will be given, unless there are special circumstances, for cancellations made within seven days of the trip date for full and half day trips, two weeks before the trip date for overnight trips and one month before the trip date for trips three days or longer. Cancellations must be made in writing via email Monday-Friday between the hours of 8am-5pm.


If you have any additional questions, contact the Adventure Shop at 828.227.8813 or basecamp@wcu.edu

Register at myrec.wcu.edu

Event.EventName: Catamounts Outdoors: Terrestrial Macroinvertebrate Hike
Event.EventDescription:
When & Where:
Meet Saturday, April 10th at 2pm-5pm, in the front lobby of the Campus Recreation Center. Please be on time!

What to Expect:
Join Base Camp and an Interpretive Ranger from Great Smokey Mountain National Park on a hike to learn more about terrestrial macroinvertebrates on WCU’s trail system. Macroinvertebrates can be found on the ground, living in trees, in webs, or flying around.  These are fascinating creatures and play a vital role in maintaining a balanced ecosystem. Participants will be empowered to discover the natural world around campus by discovering the smaller details that might not be noticed at first glance. It’s amazing how different familiar trails look when hiking with a different perspective. 

What to bring: Please plan for cool and warm weather. Below is a basic gear list that you should plan to bring inside of a small backpack.
·         Clothing appropriate for hiking, layers may be appropriate based on weather forcast
·         Small Backpack
·         Waterproof Jacket with a hood
·         Closed Toed Shoes for hiking
·         32 oz Water bottle
. *Face Covering Required
NOTICE:
You are responsible for keeping up with your own equipment and any equipment assigned to you by Base Camp Cullowhee staff. Base Camp will assume no responsibility for lost or damaged personal or rental equipment. You must immediately report injuries/medical problems to a Base Camp guide. As with most outdoor activities serious injuries can occur such as dislocations, fractures, and head injuries, however the most common injuries are bumps and bruises. Please remember that you are accepting responsibility for these risks by participating in this activity. We take all precautions and with your help we can minimize these risks.

Base Camp Cancellation Policy
 If the trip is cancelled by Base Camp Staff due to insufficient registration, unsafe conditions, or weather related circumstances patrons will receive a full refund or have the option to obtain credit towards a future outing.  If cancellation is made on the part of the patron, more than seven days before the trip date for full and half day trips, more than two weeks before the trip date for overnight trips and more than one month before the trip date for trips three days or longer, a full refund will be given.  Regardless of when you register, no refunds will be given, unless there are special circumstances, for cancellations made within seven days of the trip date for full and half day trips, two weeks before the trip date for overnight trips and one month before the trip date for trips three days or longer. Cancellations must be made in writing via email Monday-Friday between the hours of 8am-5pm.


If you have any additional questions, contact the Adventure Shop at 828.227.8813 or basecamp@wcu.edu

Register at myrec.wcu.edu

Event.EventDescription:
When & Where:
Meet Saturday, April 17th at 9am, in the front lobby of the Campus Recreation Center. Please be on time!

What to Expect:
In this workshop, participants will learn more about the flora around our WCU Trail System. Learn techniques for identifing certain types of trees and plants and some of the medicinal or helpful benefits that some plants and trees have. We will also explore a few phone apps that can help with identifying certain plants and trees. Physcial distancing and face coverings are required.

What to bring: Please plan for cool and warm weather. Below is a basic gear list that you should plan to bring inside of a small backpack.

Event.EventName: Catamounts Outdoors: Outdoor Photography 201 (Cell Phone)
Event.EventDescription:
When & Where:
Meet Wednesday, April 21st, at 5pm, in the front lobby of the Campus Recreation Center. Please be on time!

What to Expect:
In this workshop, participants will learn how to create nature photos with your phone. We will take a hike throughout the WCU trail system and discuss when and how to create a beautiful nature photo with your phone. This could be of other hikers, leaves, trees, the sky, wildlife, or more. Participants will learn the proper lighting, angles, and creative ways to help expand your nature photography with your phone. 

What to bring: Please plan for cool and warm weather. Below is a basic gear list that you should plan to bring inside of a small backpack.

Event.EventName: Catamounts Outdoors: Destressor and Mindfulness Hike
Event.EventDescription:
When & Where:
Meet Wednesday, May 5th 4pm-6pm, in the front lobby of the Campus Recreation Center. Please be on time!

What to Expect:
Looking for ways to rid the stress of the upcoming finals week? Join Base Camp Cullowhee for a relaxing and enlightening hike on WCU's Trail System. You can't be stressed and hike at the same time! While finals week comes with a lot of stress it is important to remember that it is about thriving and not just surviving. On this hike students will learn techniques for coping with the stress of finals week and the stressors of everyday life. Become grounded in our natural world through a mindfulness, breathing and other supportive techniques for coping with stress. Physical distancing and face coverings are required for participation.

What to bring: Please plan for cool and warm weather. Below is a basic gear list that you should plan to bring inside of a small backpack.
·         Clothing appropriate for hiking, layers may be appropriate based on weather forcast
·         Small Backpack
·         Waterproof Jacket with a hood
·         Closed Toed Shoes for hiking
·         32 oz Water bottle
. *Face Covering Required

NOTICE:
You are responsible for keeping up with your own equipment and any equipment assigned to you by Base Camp Cullowhee staff. Base Camp will assume no responsibility for lost or damaged personal or rental equipment. You must immediately report injuries/medical problems to a Base Camp guide. As with most outdoor activities serious injuries can occur such as dislocations, fractures, and head injuries, however the most common injuries are bumps and bruises. Please remember that you are accepting responsibility for these risks by participating in this activity. We take all precautions and with your help we can minimize these risks.

Base Camp Cancellation Policy
 If the trip is cancelled by Base Camp Staff due to insufficient registration, unsafe conditions, or weather related circumstances patrons will receive a full refund or have the option to obtain credit towards a future outing.  If cancellation is made on the part of the patron, more than seven days before the trip date for full and half day trips, more than two weeks before the trip date for overnight trips and more than one month before the trip date for trips three days or longer, a full refund will be given.  Regardless of when you register, no refunds will be given, unless there are special circumstances, for cancellations made within seven days of the trip date for full and half day trips, two weeks before the trip date for overnight trips and one month before the trip date for trips three days or longer. Cancellations must be made in writing via email Monday-Friday between the hours of 8am-5pm.


If you have any additional questions, contact the Adventure Shop at 828.227.8813 or basecamp@wcu.edu

Register at myrec.wcu.edu
